current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
Expressing the regret of the Senate for the passage of section 3 of the Expatriation Act of 1907
			 (34 Stat. 1228) that revoked the United States citizenship of women who
			 married foreign nationals.

text.#text:
expresses sincere sympathy and regret to the descendants of individuals whose
			 citizenship was revoked under

reaffirms the commitment to preserving civil rights and constitutional protections for all
			 people of the United States.

Whereas throughout the history of the United States, women have made and continue to make
			 invaluable contributions to society that strengthen the political, social,
			 and economic fabric of the Nation and improve the lives of countless
			 individuals;

Whereas women in the United States have been and continue to be leaders in promoting justice and
			 equality during times of great difficulty for the Nation;

Whereas women in the United States have played a pivotal role in ensuring freedom and security in
			 the United States;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
left thousands of women born
			 in the United States,
			 such as Elsie Knutson Moren from Minnesota and Theresa Rosella Schwan from
			 Wisconsin,  stateless and without a nationality after marrying a foreign
			 national;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 3 of the Expatriation Act of 1907

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
caused thousands of United States women, such as Lorella
			 Martorana from Pennsylvania who lost her
			 citizenship and was not able to vouch for her husband during his
			 naturalization proceedings, and Lena Weide Demke from South Dakota who
			 lost her citizenship and was almost deported during World War I, to have
			 their
			 loyalties questioned, face harassment, and be subject to deportation
			 for various legal infractions;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 3 of the Expatriation Act
			 of 1907

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
affected numerous women, such as Florence Bain
			 Gual, a
			 New York City school teacher whose tenure was stripped after 15 years
			 of teaching because she married a foreign national, causing them to face
			 difficulties
			 providing for their families because they lost, or were not able to gain,
			 public employment after marrying a foreign national;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 3 of the Expatriation Act of 1907

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
prevented women in the United States, such as
			 Ethel MacKenzie from California who was unable to register to vote because
			 she married a
			 foreign national, from participating in the political process and casting
			 ballots in various elections;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 3 of the Expatriation Act of 1907
